Here is the story of Q.E.D.’s publication, according to Ann Charters: “After Leo Stein disapproved of this autobiographical story, which Gertrude asked him to read in manuscript, she put it away and it did not resurface publicly until after her death in

Toklas sent the manuscript notebooks to Carl Van Vechten, who presented them for deposit in the Stein archives in the Beinecke Library at Yale University. “Q.E.D. was first published in 1950 with the title Things as They Are, a phrase from the end of the book chosen by her literary executors. title: Kinship, the History of Sexuality, and Native Sovereignty

Note as well Leslie Feinberg’s deployment of the history of two-­spirit people as a portal to understanding modern transgender identity—­a representation that Rifkin critiques for the ways it fetishizes Indigenous gender for the purposes of white enlightenment—­not unlike the ways someone like Charles Warren Stoddard idealizes the Indigenous cultures of the South Sea Islands as sites of sexual possibility
